subject: Ethics
title: The Encryption Backdoor Debate
description: Learn The Encryption Backdoor Debate in one minute.

hook.text: Governments want tech companies to build backdoors in encryption so police can read criminal messages.

buildup.text: End-to-end encryption means only sender and receiver can read a message. Not even the app maker can peek.

discovery.text: Law enforcement says they need access to fight terrorism and child exploitation. Without backdoors, they're blind.

twist.text: But cryptographers warn: a backdoor for the FBI is a backdoor for hackers, foreign spies, and stalkers too.

climax.text: There's no lock only good guys can open. Security is either strong for everyone or weak for everyone.

punchline.text: A door built for police doesn't check who walks through.

quiz.question: Why do cryptographers oppose encryption backdoors?
options: Any backdoor can be exploited by criminals and spies too
Encryption is already easy to break without them
